text:
It is really great
to be back here. It's been nostalgic to walk
around and meet with people and see all the little things
that have changed in the years.

So I started at UC
Berkeley in 2018. And since that time,
I've been doing

a lot of thinking
about what is it that a mechanical
designer could be doing in the space of
physical interaction?

And so I've titled
this talk "Robots that aren't afraid of contact." This is actually
after a workshop

that I cohosted at
RSS in 2022, which is called the Science
of Bumping into Things.

And really, the
idea here is that I want robots that don't have
to be super delicate, that we

can rely on, that we can
take risks with and do really cool stuff. And I do think that
mechanical design is really

at the heart of that problem. So I run the Embodied Dexterity
group-- that's what it's called. We call it EDG at Berkeley.

And so as you can
imagine, we're applying this to end effectors
a lot of the time for dextrous manipulation.

And so for today,
what I'm going to do is tell you about two
specific projects that I think are hopefully going to
expand your thinking,

whether you come from a
computer science or data science background or you come from
a mechanical background.
And here, you can see a teaser. So this is a suction cup. I love suction cups. They're great.

They don't usually break. And here, you can see it having
this kind of interesting haptic

searching behavior. It's not guided by
computer vision, and there are no electronics
in the cup itself.

And it's very cheap and
easy to make-- well, easy is all relative. We'll get to that later. But this is the
kind of interaction

that I think that we can
use to supplement things like computer vision.

So you can start guessing
how you think that works. So before going into the
details of those two projects,

I want to start with just
a little bit of my journey starting from here at Stanford. So as Mark said, I did get my
start on the Ocean One project.

And I built the hands
for this system. And one of the most poignant
moments of this project

was when we were getting
ready for a field mission, and Osama was like, you
know that if the hands fail,

we can't do nearly
a fraction of what we want to do in terms of
demonstrating the whole robot.

And that was terrifying
as a PhD student. But it was also true.

The hands and the contact points
are the conduits through which we interact with the world. And so we need to think
very carefully about them

and we need to be
able to rely on them. So what I learned
from this experience-- and it stayed with me since-- is that we need to
demonstrate resilience.

Now resilience can come
in many different forms. In this case, it
just couldn't break. But it could also be something
that's cheap or easy to replace.

Maybe you don't need
to have to recalibrate your system every time
you replace hardware-- those sorts of attributes.

So hopefully, this is
something that you take away from this talk.

Now the other major
influence for me was working under Mark Cutkosky. And this is my one of
my favorite quotes.

I use it all the
time in my talks. "Like the performance of sports
cars which ultimately is limited

by the tires on its wheels the
performance of a robotic hand is limited by the
skin on its fingers." I like this because it likens
my work to race cars, which

is super cool. But also, there's
more to this quote. It's saying that you can
have the coolest engine.

You could have the
coolest sports car you could possibly think of. But if you have bad tires, you
can't access that capability.

And in the same way, I'm
really, really excited about the skin on
our fingers and how that allows us to really embody
the full breadth of performance

that all the kinematics and
dynamics and data science and everything that we do-- that's really the conduit
through which we do our work.

So I think a lot about the
mechanics of that contact and how it interfaces with
the rest of the system.

And it became clear that when
we were working underwater-- your tires have treads.

That's because your
environment can get wet. And that changes your contact. And so we needed to
take into account

the wetness of our environment
in underwater hands. And so, of course,
you can add suction to an underwater gripper.

And this helps you grab stuff. And here are two other
explorations where we actually reverse the flow
to reduce contact

in order to move this
squishy object into the hand. And then, on this side,
there's no signals here,

but what we're doing is we're
monitoring the flow rate going through the tube. And that gives us a sense
of our contact conditions

with the world. So imagine you're drinking boba. Everybody loves boba. You can tell when one
of those tapioca balls

goes into your straw. You're not looking at it. You're not even feeling
it with your skin. This is a pressure
and flow phenomenon.

You're inferring what's
going on through that. That's kind of what's
happening here. So what I got from
these experiences

are these two other properties. So we can actually think
about our environment

in creative new ways, like,
hey, we're in a fluid. Let's not ignore that. And actually, that opens
doors to new mechanisms.

So let's harness our environment
in this contact regime. And then the second thing
is that it's really useful

to add a sense of touch, but it
doesn't always have to be hard. It doesn't always have to
be a lot of electronics.

It could be inherent
to how you're manipulating that contact. So we really want to
add that sense of touch.

Embodied intelligence
gets you a lot of the way, but we want to have
feedback control as well.

So these are the
three principles that I'm going to be
demonstrating, hopefully, throughout this talk.

And hopefully, this talk gives
you new ideas in this space. This is not meant to be a thesis
of, like, these are the three

only principles of robots
in the real world who aren't afraid of contact,
but I think they cover a lot.

So I got my start in
underwater robotics, and as Mark alluded to,
I did continue that work

in underwater systems. So here, we literally
designed treads for fingertips in
lubricated conditions

and found an optimum solution,
which is a little odd. It's not a normal skin geometry. In March of 2020, we
were in French Polynesia

doing field testing
with this spine gripper. As you can imagine,
that project did not

continue after March of 2020, so
it wasn't published very much. But we were in the field.

And we've even done
some fish-inspired work that Stanley [? Wong ?]
here contributed to. It's under review right now--

and thinking about how we can
use the fluids around the robot to do fish-inspired
manipulation.

But we evolved
outside of the ocean, and so we've also
looked at the ground

and how we can
understand the mechanics of this interaction in systems. So we designed the first
legged robot that's

able to actually pull itself-- its whole body-- underground,
which takes many times the amount of force that it
has in gravity and its weight.

We then translated some
of these modeling tools to understand how we can
drive the wheels better of a rover that is
stuck on the moon.

And actually, it
turns out that you want to drive the wheels
at different speeds, which is different from on a hard
material, where you want

them all to go the same speed. And that was just an assumption
a lot of rovers had had previously. And then we even thought
about the capstan effect

and how friction
interacts with cables in real world environments. But not as many people
work on granular media

or underwater
environments as there are people who work in the air. So I would say the vast
majority of roboticists,

especially in
academic environments, are in labs on Earth. And that Earth
has an atmosphere.

So unless you're solely working
on systems for underwater or in the vacuum of
space, air is the medium

that we need to think about. And so I'm presenting
sort of the inclusion of air in creative new ways
into our robotic grippers.

But, in fact, this
is not a new concept. How do we harness
the environment? How do we harness the air
around us in gripping?

Well, there's a couple really
straightforward and important ways that we already do this.

One is the suction cup. So suction cups do not work
in the vacuum of space.

They rely on the fact that
we have a fluid around us and it's pressurized.

So we need to have a pressure
differential between pa and pb in order for this
mechanism to work. So this is harnessing our
environment in contact.

And these are very, very
successful mechanisms. This is just a
screenshot from McMaster

showing all the different
kinds of suckers that are out. There this is not a one
and done kind of thing. There's actually quite a lot of
intricate and beautiful design

that's happening in this
space with single-cast rubber materials. And you can even see
interesting sort of porous--

this is like a granola bar-- objects that these
are able to grip onto. Now the wide variety
that is available to us

is because we need
to be able to grip onto different types
of objects and to apply different loads to them.

And so that's where we get
a lot of specialization and less generality. So how do we translate this
to more general applications.

Well, I would argue that
we need a sense of touch. So if we're going to overcome
the limitations of not being

hyperspecialized for one
specific object or scenario, then we're going to have to have
some sort of feedback control

to actively compensate
for that deficit. And I would say
that suction cups--

I mean, who here has worked with
a suction gripper at some point?

Well, my gosh, you guys get
some suction grippers in here. They're good stuff.

So what I would say is--
well, I thought everybody was going to raise their hand. But I think that one of the
reasons why these are broadly

adopted is because
they inherently demonstrate the resilience
that we need in our systems.

You can just plug
one in-- it works. If it breaks, you unplug it. You plug another one
in, and it works.

You don't need a PhD
in robot hand building to use one of these things. And again, we're
using the environment.

So that's where we leave
this last opportunity for sense of touch. So in suction grippers, this is
still an important and hot area

of research. How do we plan for and
deploy our suction grippers to grab on to,
let's say, objects

in unstructured environments? And here's a highly-cited
work from the Amazon robotics

challenge. And here, you can see that it's
trying multiple times to pick up this binder.

It fails, and then,
eventually, it succeeds. The way that this
research is often done

is really based on computer
vision or predictive planning. So can we look at a scene,
identify what we want to grasp,

and then grasp it successfully? And then the next thing
is that there can be some feedback on the suction.

So you can see that it just
lifts and then goes straight back down when it's
not successful. They are, I do believe, using
some sort of pressure sensor

to say whether it's
engaged or not. But it's treated
sort of as a binary and is not used during grasping.

And that means that,
during grasping, the grasp location
is not modified. So that's where we come in
with our smart suction cup--

to say, well, can we use
vision plus tactile sensing? So vision is going to be used to
choose the initial grasp point,

but then haptics is
used to modify it. And can we not think
of grasp success just

in these binary
terms, but if we're close to a successful grasp,
can we use that information

and move to the right location? And then, finally, we're
going to modify our grasp after initial contact.

So I asked you
earlier, if somebody-- to think about how you
thought this works,

now you can see
how close you are. So this is a single-cast
silicone rubber structure,

but there are these four
walls or four chambers that are inside of it. And so the flow
actually breaks up,

goes through all four chambers,
and then it comes back together, and it goes through
this single--

let's see-- this
single suction line. So the flow goes up
through all four chambers,

and then up and through here. These penetrate here
at a pressure sensor.

So there's no flow kind of going
through those continuously.

And each pressure
transducer is, therefore, effectively measuring the wall
pressure of this little pipe.

Whoever's taking fluids
will know that pressure is related to flow rate. So we're able to get
differential pressure
flows within this cup. Here's another look at this. So here's that connector.

So all the flow goes
up and then this way. And this is where
the flow comes in, breaks up and then
all goes through here

as it goes up into
the suction line. And this can be-- yes,
this can be quite small.

Here is the suction cup-- tada. It always looks bigger
when it's on the slides. I actually think it would
make our lives easier

if we made it bigger, but
they can be quite small. And it's done in a
single-cast silicone process.

And so, of course,
this is flow-based, so we did some
preliminary simulations to understand how the flow
would change within the cup.

And so you can see
here on the top that we've got a
leak going upwards.

So imagine you're on a PCB
with a little [? via ?] that's breaking your seal. You're going to see that flow
goes up through this chamber,

and then we're going
to get a differential pressure between the two sides. And you can have other
scenarios as well, but basically, you're able to
compare the different channels

to each other to get
that information. So here's what it
looks like when you're pulling that suction cup
off of an FTIR surface where

the bright is the contact
and the dark is no contact. And so you can see that, over
a very short period of time,

you get these kind of
catastrophic popping or breaking off failures. And what's happening
here is that you actually

have a leak point such
that the air shoots across, and so we would expect
that maximum flow would

be in the chamber four. And you can see that the
purple chamber four is lower than these other chambers
and so is getting

affected more than the others. So we're seeing sort of the
physical trends we would expect. And that's what that looks like
with the air shooting across.

So with that, we were like,
OK, this is some cool data. We've got something
physical that's happening. What do we do with it?

So we went across the hall to
Ken Goldberg and said, hey, what can we do with this data? And he was like, well,
let's do a predictive model.

So let's try to actually
feel what's happening inside of the cup to say when and
at what edge of the cup

the failure is going to occur. And we found that we
were able to somewhat do a predictive model with
just the suction cup.

And it performed very
similarly to a load cell. But it was still
really interesting and a good confirmation
that we were

able to get some predictions. So that's where we pretty much
left the failure prediction. I think there's
more to do there.

So you could imagine, as
you're picking up this object, feeling that it's torquing,
and then how it's moving,

and then actually adjusting
your grasp on the fly. But what I'm really interested
in is that old question

I brought up. So how do we actually
adjust our grasp after we're making contact? And I think one
of the reasons why

there are so many different
suction cups is because of the different materials. So you had the granola bar.

You have smooth surfaces. What if you can't perceive
the texture that's going to make or break
your suction grasp?

So for now on, I'm going to
be focusing mostly on texture. So in this video
here, what you can see

is that the suction
cup is sliding across a rough piece
of acrylic and then

a smooth piece of acrylic. And when we first
come onto the surface, we get this intermediate--
so this is just

the average of
all the chambers-- and then we get a full
engagement reading when it goes on to the smooth.

So this is how we're getting
these rich intermediate values.

So we're going to use that
information to do this. So you can see that the cup
is actually edge following.

It'll show again. So we start at this point. That's computed by vision. And then we get this interesting
edge-following behavior.

And then it
ultimately will grasp on top of an integrated circuit
and resistors and everything. So it's a bumpy surface.

But it's able to find
just the right location to grasp this successfully. So what's the controller?

How are we actually doing this? Remember, I told you
we're not using vision.

And we're just using those
for pressure sensors. It's actually shockingly simple.

So what we have is,
right here, I've labeled the four
cardinal directions.

We subtract the ones that
are opposite from each other, so I can say left or right--
which one has more suction
engagement? This one does-- go this way. That's essentially-- that's it.

And then we do it
in two directions. So that's what this is doing
is just adding those together.

We actually do
take a unit vector. That's why the motion
is just constant speed.

It's just not shown here. And then you can also do a very
similar thing using rotation. So similarly, left/right--
which one's better?

This one's better. Go towards-- or, in
that case, go this way so that this one comes
into contact better.

So you can do this in those
two different dimensions. And this is what it looks like.

So we also added
a scaling factor alpha to scale
how much we rotate versus how much we translate.

So alpha equals zero is with
rotation off, so only sliding. And then one is just rotation
about an approximate contact

point. And you can then change alpha. I believe this is alpha of 0.5,
but I don't exactly remember.

But you can see that it's
both translating and rotating. And again, only using these
for pressure sensors--

it successfully grasps. I will also note that we're
using the unit vector defined

by these four readings. We don't calibrate it. We just literally say,
like, what is your pressure?

We don't need to zero things
or do anything fancy just because we're-- basically the
way that we're using the data.

So we wanted to see if
this actually helps. So if we go back to that
bin picking challenge,

let's say we have some algorithm
that selects our initial grasp point. What we're going to
do is we're going

to use that
algorithm-- we actually got a version of Dex-Net
from Ken Goldberg. We did not retrain it.

We just changed the robot arm
and the gripper and the camera, and then just applied it. So we expect there
to be some error.

So it's going to find the
best grasp point that it thinks we should go for. We're then going to
go there and then do

sort of an iterative
search process for a certain amount of time. If the time passes and we
haven't succeeded, we fail.

If we have succeeded
at any point, meaning that we detect that our
overall pressure magnitude is

high enough to indicate
that we're fully sealed, then we're successful
when we try to move it.

And this is what
this looks like. This is real time. It's not sped up or anything. So we look at that point.

We approach the object. This is kind of
subtle, but we come in, and it's going to start
moving because it does not

detect a successful grip. And so it's going to move until
it detects that it's successful.

And then it's going to pick
up the object and move it. So would that grasp
have been successful

without haptic search? No. So that's what allowed
it to be successful.

And so we wanted to
challenge this again. So we're setting this
up for vision to fail. I know that, and
there are going to be

cases where if
vision is perfect, you don't need the
sense of touch. But we want to
challenge the system.

We want to find the role
that tactile sensing has. And so we didn't go with
basic or typical objects.

We chose adversarial objects
which, in this publication, is defined as "with few
available suction grasp points,"

meaning I give you this
object-- most of the surface would not be successful
based on suction gripping. Maybe it's porous or too bumpy.

But there's some
places to grasp. So the question is,
can we find them? And they could also be black
or shiny or transparent

or whatever feature makes
it difficult to perceive. So here are the results.

This is the just the
GPCNN predictive location.

And you can see that this is,
in fact, a very difficult task. So we only get up to about 25%
of the objects successfully

gripped. And we're allowing it to
go up to 50 total trials. Each one of these lines
is one bin-picking trial.

And then the solid
line is the average. Our best alpha, which was
0.25, which means more lateral

and a little bit
of rotation, was able to get us up to, in
the best case scenario, about 75% success.

In the worst, it was still
about the same as before. But, on average, we got a
much better improvement.

And then, just to make sure that
just randomly moving on the bin wasn't helping, we
did a random search.

So this is just
coming into that point and then randomly
moving around to see if we can get a better spot. And you can see that
it's not all that much

better than this one was.  So hopefully, what
I've shown you

is that you can start to
implement a sense of touch in a way that shouldn't
compromise your system

mechanically and can give you
some information that can make manipulation more successful.

But this is really just a start. So this is the invention
of the technology, but that leaves a lot to do
in terms of how we actually

control the system. So here, I'm going to show you
some failures, which is usually a good thing to do.

So one is oscillation,
meaning we're at a point where if
I go left or right, I keep figuring out
that I need to go back

the other way because
I'm at a local optimum, but it's not enough
to actually grip. So I'm never going to
find a better location.

Another one here is I'm
literally in contact with the object,
but it's so porous that I don't get any meaningful
change in my pressure,

or the pressure change is
the same in all directions. And then, finally, the
pushing issue, which is I'm

trying to slide my
gripper across something, and this is sticky silicone. And so it just moves the object,
so there's no relative position

change. So I think that this is kind of
an interesting place to start, thinking about other types
of controllers or designs.

For a conference paper, we
recently looked at this last one to see if we could improve this
through literally just picking

up our gripper. So if you still use
the haptic information, but then, instead
of sliding, you

just lift it every
time you take a step, the idea is that you
can overcome this issue.

Now the question was, though, as
you're touching and interacting with the object, you might
move it a little bit,

so how useful is it really? When we wanted to
try and apply this to PCB recycling handling
on conveyor lines.

So here, it's not moving. It's not on a conveyor yet. But you can see that
our haptic regrasp gets

to where it needs to
go fairly quickly, and a random search
may or may not.

And so, here, we're
calling these level 2. Level 2-- what we mean is that
there are intact integrated

circuits. And it is quite bumpy,
but it's not so bumpy, with, like, large
connectors that you would harm your suction
cup or tear it in some way

if you push too hard. Level 1 would be
it's preprocessed, and so all of the ICs
have been stripped off,

and those are just
much easier to grip. And so these ones had
the larger effect, where you when you just
have random search--

takes a lot of jumps to get
a little bit of benefit. But with the haptic search,
you get a lot of benefit within just a couple of
jumps and successfully grip.

And so here is the first
attempt on a conveyor system. As you can see, you do get
some movement of the PCB

because they're not
perfectly coordinated between the conveyor
and the arm. But we do find that, despite
this, and a very simple

vision-based center
locator, we are able to improve grasping
on the next attempt.

And we can improve it just
by trying again quite a bit. Now we didn't find that the
effect of haptics versus random

was smaller because
we're moving the object. So the haptic search is going
to respond in a way that

is seemingly more random. And so this is where I
think there's an opportunity to bring computer vision to,
then, adjust for object movement

at the same time. All right, this is under
review, so hopefully, we'll find out sooner or later
whether it's accepted.

So I'm finishing up
on this project now, where I think I just
wanted to pitch this.

I think I've got a
bunch of students here who are-- hopefully
some of which doing a robot manipulation.

Maybe some of you will get
more into suction cups. But I'm right across
the Bay, and I'm

ready to see this
technology translate. So it is still in its
prototyping phase.

It may still tear
and may still break. But I would really love to work
with researchers, especially

in computer vision
labs, in labs that are more CS-based, to see
if we can work together

to make this the next GelSight. Everybody uses GelSight. Well, could this be the
GelSight of suction cups?

That's kind of my hope. So if you want to work with
me on that, please reach out.

So I'm going to transition
now to another tactile sensing technology. And I want to pause just
to talk a little bit more

in depth about sensor
integration into soft structures because a lot of hands are soft.

So what I'm going to do
is plot a couple different just example technologies. And what I want to show
you is the distance

from the contact
to the transducer. So the transducer
is the element that

is translating your physical
stimulus to electrical signals.

So this is usually
where you have the introduction of electronics
as well as some need to have batteries or wireless
communication or wires.

And so that, to me, is where a
lot of potential failure points emerge-- wires are the worst.

So starting at the closest side,
you have a lot of technologies. You've got capacitive.

Here, we've got a
force-sensitive resistor. We've also got some
really cool sort of fluid channel-type
technologies

that are integrated directly
into the gripper itself. And if we move a
little bit farther,

you start to get some
interesting new technologies. Well, I think they're
new, but let's just

say they're less common. But they've been
around for a while. But acoustic-- so you can use
acoustics within structures

to understand sort
of where contact is and get your transducer just
a little bit farther away

from that contact point. And then vision-- we've
got GelSight, which could be centimeters away.

And people are working to
move it farther and farther away from that contact
point for resiliency.

And then I've even
showed you today an example of a connected device
where the transducer, the flow,

can be very far
away, but it's still sort of through these
channels and tubes. And some other people have
done various pressure fluids

and stuff. Now the last category, the
one that's the farthest away,

is where you basically are
transmitting the information through air. So you could do this with sight.

You just have a
camera, and you're looking at your manipulation. You can infer things
about contact. And same with sound-- you
can listen to the contacts

as they're happening and
infer what's going on. And those are great
because you just need a camera or a microphone.

Anybody can do that. And so we can bridge
this entire spectrum.

And while it's not a
hard and fast rule, I would generally say that
ease of adoption and resilience

tends to get better as you
move farther and farther away from the contact point. But there is this
issue that I see

where the reason why we
want tactile sensors closer to the contact is so that we
can measure things directly,

like force and pressure. That's physically relevant--
versus on this side,

you have to just
infer what's going on. It's just a different type
of interpretation problem.

But on this side, you need
to be physically connected. You need tubes or
wires or something. And on this side, you
get the benefit of not.

So what I want to do is do both. So I want a tactile sensor
that's measuring something

like normal force,
something I want, but have it not be physically connected.

So let's think about air. Air-- we can use it
as a sensing medium.

That's what I've
shown you already. As flow is going into
and out of our system, we can measure how that
action is happening.

The flow is also an actuator. So think of a flute. I think a flute is a
beautiful touch sensor.

You put air over this part. So you're actuating it. When I say actuation,
I mean vibrations.

And then you change the
contact state of this device, and it makes beautiful
different frequencies.

So our measurement is frequency. We can do that using
just a simple microphone. And guess what?

You could have a whole
orchestra of flutes playing all sorts of different notes,
and you can detect those, again, with a single microphone.

So this is the kind of
transmission of information that I'd like to have.
So here's our flute. [WHISTLING]

And this is where it gets
a little more interesting. [OVERLAPPING WHISTLING]

So hopefully, that reminds
you of childhood and playing with toy trains or whatever you
did with musical instruments.

But what we're calling
this is AcousTac. So it's acoustic-based
tactile sensing, where--

when I say not connected,
I do acknowledge that there is a pump. So the actuator is connected.

But the sensing itself is not. So it's going through
the air as sound.

And so here we have what's a
tin whistle, which is probably closest to what I just showed
you, where the red part is

called the fipple. This is the knife edge, where
the flow is going to go across and actually oscillate
against that knife edge

to create the vibrations. And then we've got the resonant
tube, which kind of manipulates the frequency in different
ways based on length and holes

and so forth. So this is what one of the
taxels, or tactile pixels, looks like, where we have
a 3D-printed structure

with the knife edge and with
part of the resonant tube here. And then this is what that would
look like from the top and then
from the side. Of course, it makes sound. And so how does this work?

Well, just to give you
some intuition, what we have is the function of
frequency getting emitted

is inversely related
to the length. So we have this
compliant cap at the end,

and as we apply a
force, it will compress, which will reduce
the effect of length. And therefore, it's going
to increase the frequency.

So that's it. And this is assuming
very simple harmonics. It's more just for
understanding, not necessarily like a true model.

So we did some
testing of this just to calibrate and understand. And so this is what, generally,
the signals will look like.

and so that's how we get a
single line from the data. So this is what it looks like

of them. So what we've done is we've

And this would be
a very simple way to get multiple measures

and then gets loud, versus
the one that's always closed is always very loud.

And so you could create
an amplitude threshold, then filter out when

And so, of course, if

based on the size of the hole. And, in fact, if you want to

makes sound. And this is what it's going to

So, to conclude,
these are the tenants that I've been really
fascinated with. We want to make sure that we're
harnessing the environment maybe

in ways that you haven't
always thought about. So think about the
air that you're in and how this can
influence your designs.

We need to demonstrate
resilience. At the end of the
day, robots are not going to make an impact unless
people can rely on them.

And I feel very
strongly about that, and that's why we've done this
exploration of these really passive interesting structures.

And then, finally, though, just
because embodied intelligence morphological
computation is great

doesn't mean that we
shouldn't have active sensing. So I think it would be a mistake
to just ignore that altogether.

Every sensing modality might not
make sense in every scenario, but I think it would be a little
bit silly to just ignore it

altogether. And then I want to thank and
